data.title: Lightbulb is only visible when you can see the first column
data.body: This means you cannot see that code actions are available when authoring relatively long lines on a narrow monitor.

data.title: Incorrect comment type within script blocks inside of markdown files
data.body:
**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. In a markdown file, write:
```md
<script>
1 + 1
</script>
```

2. Place cursor on the line `1 + 1` and trigger a line comment

**Expected**
```md
<script>
// 1 + 1
</script>
```

**Actual**
```md
<script>
<!-- 1 + 1 -->
</script>
```

data.title: Use embeddedLanguages to mark markdown fenced code block content types
data.body:
**Bug**
Inside markdown fenced code blocks, the language mode is always markdown. This prevents backet matching, code commenting, and other editor features from working properly for the language within the code block

**Proposed fix**
Register `embeddedLanguages` for markdown to map fenced code block language scopes back to the correct language mode

data.title: Add CodeAction interface
Search returns incorrect results for files that have only \r newlines
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:09.760Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-sidebar|Acr|1.0.0
gauntletTest|Mic|2.3.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Clone intunedocs-pr
2. In VSCode, open the repo folder, shift-control-F, and search on "ms.assetid:". 
3. Search returns 653 results in 572 files. There should be only one in each file. I ran the same search in NotePad ++ and got 571 hits in 571 files (exactly what I would expect).
4. Scroll down to one of the files in VSCode that contain 2 hits and click on of the ms.assetid's, see capture below: 
 ![screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1141590/30566937-edb52746-9c82-11e7-802c-16d3efd8c99c.png)
 The highlighted text in the opened file is not the search text. If you click the other hit, it doesn't highlight the text correctly either. Note that there's just one instance of the the search text in the file. 

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Add trigger type to CodeActionContext
[Feature Request] VSCode TypeScript extension exported things + auto import
data.body:
The intellisense doesn't show the exported classes, functions, enums, ... in the actual workspace.
I know there's extension that allow to make that, but the native extension working with the great TSServer running will be amazing for that !
Also, the diagnostic logic of typescript already proprose to import something with the bulblight after we type the complete name of the exported thing, and it works like a charm with baseUrl and already imported section. Why don't propose an option to autoimport after hitting the completion key on the intellisense window ?

data.title: Node v8.5.0 breaks the "uncaught exception" setting
Add TM_FILEPATH_RELATIVE snippet variable
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: all
- OS Version: all

I have a lot of snippets for my projects and I often use variables.
`TM_FILEPATH` - it's good, but sometimes project has very long path, something like:
`/home/user/Documents/work/project1/frontEnd/bestUi/src/component/modal/utils/view.js`
My root folder in vsCode is `bestUi` I don't need to print or use all path, just path from root-folder to file:
`/bestUi/src/component/modal/utils/view.js`,
My proposal is to add new variable, called `TM_FILEPATH_RELATIVE`, which return, only path from root-folder to file.
If this proposal is being interesting for community, I can implement it, added test for that, add support for multi root-folders and so on,
Just one question, I cannot understand - Where is vsCode saving information about root folder of project?
Thanks a lot for all discussions.

data.title: [Feature Request] Sticky Tabs
data.body:
I'd like to stick a tab somehow. In the way that I could close all tabs, but the sticky ones. 

Maybe even we could manage groups of tabs, but that could be beyond this. :P. With the stick ability I'll work fine. Thanks! (And sorry if this is someone duplicate, I tried to search for it).

data.title: Which version of JSON schema is VSCODE supporting?
data.body:
The documentation (https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/json) does not say specific version.  I know that VSCode supports draft-04 for sure as I am using it, but I wonder if it supports draft-06 too.  

Note that I originally asked this on [stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46205308) but was suggested to ask here. In any case, it is probably worth updating the documentation anyway.  

Thanks!

data.title: Specific focus mode for popup?
data.body: I was trying to assign a specific shortcut key (instead of `esc`) to dismiss popup/tooltip box (as seen pointed by the red arrow in the screenshot). Wondering if there's a specific focus mode I could use to target it? Something like `"when": "editorFocus"` but for popups instead?

data.title: Assertion failed - node-pty/winpty
data.body:
Receiving the following error upon VSCode Insiders startup:

![Error Screenshot](https://i.imgur.com/no0AE7C.png)

The terminal then closes and shows the following error in VSCode Insiders:
> The terminal process terminated with exit code: 3221226505

- VSCode Version: 1.17.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10 Home

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Close VSCode while bash terminal is open (nothing running)
2. Open VSCode Insiders manually, or through `code-insiders .`, or through `code-insiders --disable-extensions`
3. Error appears

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: C++ intelliSense with different file system types (Windows 10)
data.body: - VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (128a4e3640c5375f7b0bc1cfd37f626481b1386f, 2017-09-12T05:24:19.607Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063 - Extensions: Extension|Author (truncated)|Version ---|---|--- cpptools|ms-|0.12.4 IntelliSense doesn't seem to be working with SSHFS filesystem type in Windows 10 (no import errors detected and no squiggly lines). I know this is a fringe case, but I'm wondering if there is an easy fix. IntelliSense works fine for this example in the local filesystem as well as on an exfat formatted flash drive. --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. Install winsshfs and mount a remote file system 2. Open the a project locally from that mounted file system Reproduces without extensions: No (Need the C++ extension for intellisense)

- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Mac OS X Yosemite 10.10.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VSCode.
2. Open System Preferences.app.
3. Click Dock.
4. Check 'Double-click a window's title bar to minimize'.
5. Double-click the title bar in the VSCode window. The window will expand to fill the screen when it should minimize to the Dock.

data.title: Explorer contribution state should be persisted globally, not on a workspace basis
data.body:
When the user decides to hide or show an Explorer contribution, that setting is persisted on a workspace by workspace basis.  I think it should be global instead.

This comes from: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-docker/issues/124 where I actually removed a configuration option to hide/show the explorer contribution because the user could right click and say "Hide...". I didn't realize this was on a workspace basis, I assumed global.

I see this with other things too. If i choose to hide the "Open Editors" section of the Explorer, its not because I don't want to see it on this workspace, it is a global statement where I say I don't want to see this sash.  

For every extension I install that has an explorer contribution, I have to turn it off on every workspace I open. For example, the XML Tools extension contributes an XML explorer that I rarely need (I wanted formatting). So now I have to turn off this contribution on every folder I open.

data.title: Support actions to show up in the macOS touchbar
data.body: Ref: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14653 Enables support for commands to show up in the macOS touch bar. The ID for this menu is `touchBar`. We require the icon for the command to be a PNG, as the API currently does not support SVG. First use cases: * editor history navigation * new file * debug tool bar
